Framework vs. Framework Skeleton vs. Services – Web Client Software Factory Example

Posted by davidhayden on June 6, 2007

Ayende mentions the idea of Framework vs. Services and relates it to the CAB discussion:


“Frameworks have a much higher adoption cost associated with them vs. services. Services are more easily compassable and replaceable.”


I agree with that.


Brad Wilson mentions the same thing in his post, Frameworks vs. Libraries,  which was about CAB ( and Enterprise Library ) and initially got me thinking about the differences:


“I can take an existing application and add logging with log4net, because it makes very few demands on me. I basically make calls to it. Using CAB in an application is a commitment, because it describes the way you should build your application. It’s a framework, and in most cases, it’s calling me rather than me calling it. Peter’s “easy test” to tell a framework from a library is the Hollywood principal: if the thing is always saying “Don’t call me, I’ll call you”, then it’s a framework.


There’s no question that the investment required to use a framework is significantly larger than the investment required to use a library.”


Ayende then mentions Ruby on Rails and calls it more of a Framework Skeleton:


“Well, I don’t see RoR as a framework, it is a Framework Skeleton, and filling this skeleton there is a set of independent services that can be used to build your application. This approach means that you can:




  • Replace the services with your own implementations


  • Use the services outside the framework”

This is EXACTLY the point I am making with the Web Client Software Factory and the need for Enterprise Library to be separated out. ( Vote here ).


When Enterprise Library became a part of the Web Client Software Factory it immediately went from a Framework Skeleton to a Framework. I now cannot easily create a solution just using log4net and SubSonic without Enterprise Library getting in the way. Enterprise Library is hardcoded into the guidance packages, recipes, and configuration files.


We need to pull out the Enterprise Library Dependency because the Web Client Software Factory has a larger target audience than Enterprise Library.


This isn’t to say that P&P doesn’t take advantage of Enterprise Library 3.1 Features for those wanting to go the Enterprise Library route. In fact this is a big demand as voted on by the community. It just means developers not using Enterprise Library don’t have to pay for the extra baggage when they don’t need that level of infrastructure services and/or want to use a different package.


The Web Client Software Factory needs to be an awesome Framework Skeleton with some optional kickass bells and whistles.


by David Hayden

3 Responses to Framework vs. Framework Skeleton vs. Services – Web Client Software Factory Example

  1. Benjy says:
    June 16, 2007 at 7:16 pm

    Hi, Good comment regarding entlib. Im more of a biztalk/ webservice person myself and have just started looking at WCSF and I like entlib but i think that WCSF would be doing itself a disservice by insisting on entlib instead of applying some DI technique to allow you to use anything you want (even NHibernate). Similarly, i think that a variant of the factory for MonoRail users and others who use things like NMVP might also be very useful as it would increase adoption of factories in general.
    btw, keep up the great work with the screencasts and great posts.
    cheers,
    benjy

  2. David Hayden says:
    June 7, 2007 at 2:38 pm

    Bob,

    I don’t have any experience with RoR so you may be right. My guess is that one person’s Framework Skeleton is probably another person’s Framework.

    It is probably hard to add real value sometimes without finding some sort of compromise. Often this becomes the well-known convention over configuration, which may not play well in certain environments as well as legacy environments.

    In my case, I think the WCSF has gone a little too far by forcing an integration of Enterprise Library, which suggests Enterprise Library or the highway. Change that dependency to an option in version 2.0 and strengthen the core dependency injection and UI services and you have yourself a solid framework skeleton.

  3. Bob says:
    June 7, 2007 at 2:22 am

    I agree with your meta-principle about framework skeletons, but think Ayende’s example of RoR as a framework skeleton is wrong.

    One of the things that put me off about rails is how much of a “my way or the highway” approach it takes. It is not as pluggable or extensible as more general frameworks.
